question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a full Production Target disclosure, when can it leave out the detailed assumptions and proportion breakdown in a later update, and what does it still need to say in that later update (including any special warning statements)?
gold_answer: In its disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2, a Mining Reporting Entity must include key details about how the Production Target was determined, including the material economic assumptions (or, if commercially sensitive, a statement that they are commercially sensitive and an explanation of the methodology used), all other material assumptions, any statement about forecast commodity pricing being arrived at on reasonable grounds, and the proportions of the Production Target based on Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources (including Inferred Mineral Resources), and any Exploration Target, plus the required viability and cautionary statements where applicable [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. After it has made that earlier disclosure and it was compliant with the information requirements that would otherwise need to be repeated, the Mining Reporting Entity may make a later disclosure about the Production Target without re-including that otherwise-required information, but only if the later disclosure (1) points back to the earlier compliant disclosure and (2) confirms that the material assumptions in the initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]. Also, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate warning statement if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, and must include a similarly prominent proximate warning statement if the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef].
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: When an Authorised Person calculates PSIACOMcredit contract by contract, what must it do if the CR Exposure is still current (not past due for more than 90 days), and how does that affect the step where it sets the contract’s risk weighting or capital charge before using the PSIACOMcredit formula?
gold_answer: For each Islamic Contract included in PSIACOMcredit, an Authorised Person must run through a contract-level process: identify the relevant Islamic Contracts, value the underlying investment or asset for each one, and reduce that value as required to arrive at the contract-specific value used in the PSIACOMcredit calculation [#SRC:ad52577a-53d9-469d-ba7a-ae9b4c0a7787]. If the contract results in a CR Exposure that is not past due for more than 90 days, the Authorised Person must categorise that exposure into one of the specified asset classes (for example, cash items, central government/central bank, bank, corporate, regulatory retail, residential mortgage, commercial real estate, or other Exposures) [#TGT:0699660d-a2de-4359-8468-2d993b6a712f]. This categorisation is the required classification step that the Authorised Person must have in place when it determines the risk weighting or capital charge (CRW) appropriate to the contract. Once the CRW is determined, the Authorised Person applies the relevant formula to calculate PSIACOMcredit for that contract and then sums the PSIACOMcredit across all contracts to determine the total PSIACOMcredit applicable to the Authorised Person [#SRC:ad52577a-53d9-469d-ba7a-ae9b4c0a7787].

question: If an Authorised Person uses the FCSA and has eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure, what does it need to do to calculate RWA while recognising the collateral’s CRM effect—especially how it sets E and which risk weight it applies to each part?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate its RWA for CR Exposures by first calculating the Exposure value (E) for each relevant asset using the required exposure measurement methodology and by recognising the effects of any applicable CRM as part of that calculation [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368]. If it has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA, it may recognise the CRM effect by dividing the exposure into a collateralised portion and an uncollateralised portion [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb]. For the collateralised portion, it sets E equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral and applies the risk weight (CRW) that would apply to that collateral as if the Authorised Person had a direct exposure to it. For the uncollateralised portion, it sets E equal to the E of the CR Exposure minus the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral and applies the risk weight that is applicable to the obligor. It then calculates RWA amounts using E multiplied by the applicable risk weight and adds up the RWA amounts across all CR Exposures [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368].
source_text:
Recognition of eligible financial Collateral under FCSA. Subject to A4.3.28, an Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may recognise the effects of CRM of the eligible financial Collateral as follows:
(a) 	break down the Exposure into -
(i) 	a collateralised portion with E equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and
(ii) 	an uncollateralised portion with E equal to the E of the CR Exposure less the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral;
and
(b) 	for the purposes of calculating the Credit RWA amount pursuant to Rule 4.8.3, use:
(i) 	for the collateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the eligible financial Collateral as though the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to that Collateral; and
(ii) 	for the uncollateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the obligor.

question: Where a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator is treated as liable for a Prospectus and an investor claims compensation for loss arising from an untrue or misleading statement or a material omission, what must that prescribed person demonstrate or have done to avoid incurring civil liability, including any steps required before the Securities were acquired in reliance on the Prospectus?
gold_answer: Under the compensation regime, any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to a person who acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and suffered loss or damage arising from an untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission of a material matter required to be included [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. However, that person does not incur civil liability if they can show one of the specified bases: that the statement was true and not false, misleading, or deceptive, or that the matter whose omission caused the loss was properly omitted; or that they made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or that, before the Securities were acquired by any person in reliance on the Prospectus, they took all steps reasonable for them to take to secure that a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of persons likely to acquire the Securities [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554].
source_text:
A Person does not incur civil liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR if that Person can show that:
(a)	the statement was true and not false, misleading, or deceptive or that the matter the omission of which caused the loss was properly omitted;
(b)	he made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed that there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or
(c)	before the Securities were acquired by any Person in reliance on the Prospectus, he had taken all such steps as were reasonable for him to have taken to secure that a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of the Persons likely to acquire the Securities in question.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: If an Authorised Person is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, what extra rulebooks must it comply with, and when it applies the GEN rule that covers it, what word change must it make so the rule fits Virtual Assets?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, compliance is not limited to the general requirements that apply to an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets; it must also comply with additional requirements that include COBS, MIR and GEN [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24]. The GEN element is made more specific by the statement that GEN Rule 5.2.14 applies to that same type of Authorised Person and activity [#TGT:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705]. When applying that GEN rule in the Virtual Asset context, the firm must follow an explicit reading instruction: every reference to “Investment” in the GEN rule must be read as a reference to “Virtual Asset” [#TGT:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705]. In practice, this means the firm should treat the GEN rule’s obligations as fully applicable to its Virtual Asset Multilateral Trading Facility operations, but interpret the rule’s terminology so that it is aligned to Virtual Assets rather than Investments, while still meeting the broader set of additional requirements identified for this activity [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24] [#TGT:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705].
source_text:
In addition to the general requirements applicable to an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets as set out in Rules 17.1 – 17.6, an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets must comply with the requirements set out in:
(a)	COBS, MIR and GEN, as set out in Rules 17.7.2 – 17.7.6; and
(b)	Rule 17.8 if also Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets.
target_text: GEN Rule 5.2.14 shall apply to an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, and all references to “Investment” shall be read as references to “Virtual Asset”.

question: What must an Authorised Person do to keep professional indemnity insurance in place, what should the policy cover (including Employee-related claims and legal costs), and what does it have to send or report to the Regulator over time?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must take out and maintain professional indemnity insurance cover that fits the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of its business, so the cover needs to be tailored to how the business operates and the risks it faces [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b]. In meeting that requirement, the insurance should be arranged under a contract with a reputable and well capitalised Insurer, and it should cover claims where the Authorised Person may be liable because of the conduct of the Authorised Person itself and its Employees [#SRC:3c5ec7af-6f4a-41d7-988c-13494992bc71]. The cover should also include appropriate protection for legal costs that arise from a claim, so the policy responds not only to damages or liability exposure but also to associated legal expense [#SRC:3c5ec7af-6f4a-41d7-988c-13494992bc71]. Ongoing, the Authorised Person must provide the Regulator with a copy of the insurance at least annually for the next 12 months and be able to demonstrate that the cover is adequate for its business profile [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b]. It must also notify the Regulator of any material changes, including changes in the level of cover and any renewal or termination [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b].
source_text: In complying with Rule 6.12.2, an Authorised Person should take out and maintain a contract for professional indemnity insurance (PII) from a reputable and well capitalised Insurer and such contract should include cover in respect of claims for which the Authorised Person may be liable as a result of the conduct of itself and its Employees and appropriate cover in respect of legal costs arising from a claim.
target_text:
An Authorised Person must:
(a)	subject to Rule 6.12A, take out and maintain professional indemnity insurance cover appropriate to the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of the Authorised Person's business;
(b)	at least annually, provide the Regulator with a copy of the professional indemnity insurance cover in (a) covering the following 12 month period and be able to demonstrate its adequacy in relation to the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of the Authorised Person’s business; and
(c)	notify the Regulator of any material changes to the cover in (a), including the level of cover, its renewal or termination.

question: When a Supplementary Prospectus is filed, under what circumstances may the Regulator require payment of a supplementary fee, and how does that align with the broader situations in which the Regulator is permitted to impose a supplementary fee for substantial additional cost or effort?
gold_answer: Across both provisions, the Regulator’s ability to impose a supplementary fee is framed as a conditional permission tied to expected substantial additional cost or effort. In the specific context of filing a Supplementary Prospectus, the default position is that filing alone does not lead to any fee; however, if the review of that Supplementary Prospectus will require the Regulator to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in conducting its review, the Regulator may require payment of a supplementary fee [#SRC:cec237a1-c364-4ed0-9197-dcac6160defb]. The broader permission confirms the same underlying threshold—where the Regulator expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort—and clarifies that this may arise not only in review of a filing but also in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Read together, the Supplementary Prospectus scenario is an example of the wider category: a filing that, due to the anticipated burden on the Regulator, can justify a supplementary fee, but only when the substantial-cost/effort condition is met.
source_text: The filing of a Supplementary Prospectus does not trigger the payment of a fee unless the review of the Supplementary Prospectus will require the Regulator to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort when conducting its review, in which event the Regulator may require payment of a supplementary fee in accordance with Rule 1.2.4.
target_text:
Supplementary fees
The Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee in circumstances where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing or when conducting on-going supervision.

question: If the Third Party Provider confirms a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, and it causes an unauthorised Payment Transaction, who must be refunded and how quickly must the Third Party Provider make the refund?
gold_answer: Once the Third Party Provider has confirmed that a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide a refund as soon as practicable and no later than the end of the next day after the day it made that confirmation [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. If the situation also meets the additional conditions that an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with the relevant authorisation requirement and that it leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, then the Third Party Provider must make refunds to two recipients, subject to the stated rules: it must refund the Primary Financial Institution for any amount the Primary Financial Institution may already have refunded to the Customer, and it must refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, minus any amount the Third Party Provider has refunded to the Primary Financial Institution [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe]. In practice, this means the Third Party Provider must act quickly after confirmation, and it must ensure the Customer is made whole while avoiding paying the same amount twice when the Primary Financial Institution has already reimbursed the Customer.
source_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable, and in any event no later than the end of the day following the day on which it has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed.
target_text:
Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. Subject to Rules 20.10 and 20.11, where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 20.7 and the Third Party Transaction leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider must:
(a)	refund the Primary Financial Institution for the amount that the Primary Financial Institution may have already refunded to the Customer; and
(b)	refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, less any amount that the Third Party Provider has refunded to the Primary Financial Institution.

question: When compiling the Resolution Pack for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, what must the Authorised Person do to ensure the required master list of all Client Accounts is maintained and sufficiently detailed, and which specific account attributes must be captured to meet the record-keeping obligation?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must ensure that the Resolution Pack includes the required records relating to master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. To satisfy that inclusion requirement, the Authorised Person must also maintain a master list of all Client Accounts and ensure the list contains the prescribed level of detail [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d]. Specifically, the master list must capture, for each Client Account, the account name and account number, where the account is located, and the bank’s identity together with its address and contact information. It must also record the account’s terms and conditions, indicate whether the account is currently open or closed, and include the date the account was opened or closed. In practice, the Authorised Person should treat the maintained master list as the authoritative source document that is then included within the Resolution Pack, ensuring the pack reflects the same complete set of required fields for all Client Accounts relevant to Client Money and Client investments.

question: If a Fund Manager is arranging for a Fund Auditor’s Report, what are the two main things it must do: one about the audit itself and one about what the report must cover?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager has two connected duties: one is to make sure the audit is carried out properly, and the other is to make sure the report contains the required conclusions. On the audit side, the Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to conduct an audit of the Fund’s financial statements in accordance with the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB), and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on the audited financial statements [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579]. On the report side, when procuring the production of the Fund Auditor’s Report, the Fund Manager must ensure that an Auditor states whether the financial statements were properly prepared under the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund, and whether they give a true and fair view of the Fund’s (or Sub-Fund’s) financial position and results for the annual accounting period and at the end of that period [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]. It must also ensure the report addresses whether proper accounting records have not been kept or the statements do not agree with records/returns or do not comply with applicable standards, whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, whether the Directors’ report or the Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, and any other matter required by FUNDS [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce].
source_text:
Function of the Auditor. A Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to:
(a)	conduct an audit of the Fund's financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB); and
(b)	produce a Fund Auditor's Report on the audited financial statements in accordance with GEN Rule 6.6.8.

question: If the Listing Authority looks into a complaint and decides the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not exempt from Disclosure, what does it ask the Reporting Entity to do, and what usually happens after an ‘aware letter’ is sent and the Reporting Entity replies?
gold_answer: When the Listing Authority investigates a complaint or allegation of non-compliance and, as a result of that enquiry, forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within an exemption from Disclosure, it will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944]. If the Listing Authority also considers that the information should have been Disclosed earlier, it may issue an ‘aware letter’ (or take other relevant action), signalling that the Listing Authority is focusing on the timeliness of the Reporting Entity’s Disclosures [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944]. After an ‘aware letter’ has been issued, the Reporting Entity provides a response. The Listing Authority then receives and reviews that response, and once it has done so, it will usually Disclose both the ‘aware letter’ and the Reporting Entity’s response together. This joint Disclosure is intended to ensure the market in the Listed Entity’s Securities is aware that the Listing Authority has made enquiries about the timeliness of Disclosures and is also aware of the Reporting Entity’s response to those enquiries [#TGT:f4e70987-8287-425e-a207-54a123dfa6f4].
source_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Complaints or allegations of non-compliance by Reporting Entities
If, as a result of the enquiry, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within exemption from Disclosure provided by Rule 7.2.2, the Listing Authority will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1.  If the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an ‘aware letter’ (see paragraphs 187 to 189 above), or take other relevant action.
target_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Aware Letters
When a Reporting Entity’s response has been received and reviewed by the Listing Authority, both the ‘aware letter’ and the Reporting Entity’s response will usually be Disclosed together by the Listing Authority, so that the market in the Listed Entity’s Securities is aware that the Listing Authority has made enquiries of the Reporting Entity about the timeliness of its Disclosures, and of the Reporting Entity’s response to those enquiries.

question: When the Regulator receives a Host Regulator request to conduct an on-site inspection relating to a Passported Fund, is the Regulator permitted to decline to cooperate, and if so how does that interact with the requirement to allow the inspection and accompany it during the visit?
gold_answer: When the Regulator receives a request from a Host Regulator to carry out an on-site inspection in relation to a Passported Fund, the Regulator is required to permit the inspection and to accompany it during the on-site inspection [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6]. However, the Regulator also has discretion to refuse to act on a Host Regulator’s request for cooperation in relation to an inspection in specified circumstances [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c]. Those circumstances are limited to situations where the Regulator has already commenced or concluded enforcement action concerning the same conduct and the same Persons, or where judicial proceedings have already been initiated or concluded concerning the same conduct and the same Persons [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c]. Read together, the default position is that the Regulator must facilitate and attend the on-site inspection when requested, but it may decline to act on the cooperation request where one of the listed enforcement-action or judicial-proceedings conditions applies, because the refusal power is expressly tied to cooperation in relation to an inspection [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c].
source_text: Where the Regulator receives a request from a Host Regulator to carry out an on-site inspection in relation to a Passported Fund, the Regulator shall, subject to Rule 9.3.2, permit such inspection and accompany it during the on-site inspection.
target_text:
The Regulator may refuse to act on a request by a Host Regulator for cooperation in relation to an inspection in the following circumstances:
(a)	the Regulator has already commenced, or concluded, enforcement action in respect of the same conduct and the same Persons; or
(b)	judicial proceedings have already been initiated, or concluded, in respect of the same conduct and the same Persons.

question: If an Authorised Person is preparing the Resolution Pack while conducting Investment Business, what must they do about the master list of all Client Accounts, and what details must that list include for each account?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must ensure the Resolution Pack contains the required records, including the master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. To be able to include that record properly, the Authorised Person must maintain a master list of all Client Accounts and make sure it is complete and detailed in the way required [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d]. For each Client Account, the list must state the account’s name and number, where the account is located, and the bank’s name along with the bank’s address and contact information. It must also include the account’s terms and conditions, show whether the account is open or closed, and record the date the account was opened or closed. This means the maintained master list should be kept up to date so that, when the Resolution Pack is assembled, the included master list already contains all required fields for every relevant Client Account.

question: When an Authorised Person is required to choose between the Financial Collateral Simplified Approach and the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, how is the scope of “eligible financial Collateral” defined for an Authorised Person using the FCCA, and how does that definition relate to the treatment adopted under the Simplified Approach?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral by using either the Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) or the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA) [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19]. Where the Authorised Person uses the FCCA, “eligible financial Collateral” is defined to include three categories: (1) any instrument listed in the referenced list; (2) any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and (3) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in those traded equity Securities, provided the Unit price is publicly quoted daily and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments covered by the FCCA list and the referenced list [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]. This FCCA definition is relevant to the required approach selection because the FCSA is described as adopting the treatment under the same referenced list “in relation to the composition of financial Collateral,” while the FCCA adopts a different treatment and then specifies, by definition, what collateral is eligible under that approach [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19] [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85].
source_text:
An Authorised Person must use either the:
(a)	Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.5 in relation to the composition of financial Collateral; or
(b)	Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.6;
to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: If an Authorised Person is working out CET1 deductions for investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities, what calculation basis must be used for Trading Book holdings (including any netting rules), and what is the general rule about using gross long positions?
gold_answer: The two texts together require the Authorised Person to apply a general calculation principle while also following a specific Trading Book method when it applies. The SOURCE states that, for the relevant purposes, the amount of holdings of CET1 Capital instruments and other capital instruments of Relevant Entities to be deducted must be calculated on the basis of gross long positions (and it notes this is subject to another rule) [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454]. The TARGET then explains that, for the relevant purposes, an Authorised Person must make the deductions by calculating holdings in the Trading Book on the basis of the net long position in the same underlying Exposure, but only if the short position’s maturity matches the long position’s maturity or the short has a residual maturity of at least one year [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c]. In practice, this means the gross long position basis is the general approach, while Trading Book holdings can be reduced to a net long position only where the offsetting short position meets the maturity conditions and relates to the same underlying Exposure.
source_text: CET1 Deductions - investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(f), (g) and (h), the amount of holdings of CET1 Capital instruments and other capital instruments of Relevant Entities to be deducted, must be calculated, subject to Rule 3.10.15, on the basis of the gross long positions.
target_text:
CET1 Deductions - investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), an Authorised Person must make the deductions in accordance with the following:
(a)	the holdings in the Trading Book of the capital instruments of Relevant Entities must be calculated on the basis of the net long position in the same underlying Exposure provided the maturity of the short position matches the maturity of the long position or has a residual maturity of at least one year; and
(b)	the amount to be deducted for indirect holdings in the Trading Book of the capital instruments of Relevant Entities that take the form of holdings of index Securities must be determined by calculating the underlying Exposure to the capital instruments of the Relevant Entities in the indices.

question: When a FinTech Participant cannot meet the applicable criteria, in what circumstances must it stop carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab, and how does the Regulator’s own-initiative variation or cancellation of a Financial Services Permission affect the timing of that cessation?
gold_answer: Where the FinTech Participant is unable to satisfy the applicable criteria, it must cease carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7]. The timing is bounded by two alternative triggers: (i) the expiry of its RegLab FSP, reflecting the stated two-year validity period, or (ii) an earlier point in time if the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7]. The TARGET clarifies the relevant scope of that second trigger by identifying that the variation or cancellation is one undertaken on the initiative of the Regulator, and that it concerns variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a]. Accordingly, the obligation to stop the Regulated Activity applies once the FinTech Participant cannot meet the criteria, and the cessation deadline is either at permission expiry or at the point the Regulator, acting on its own initiative, varies or cancels the Financial Services Permission, whichever occurs first in practice.
source_text: Two-year validity period. If the FinTech Participant is unable to satisfy the above criteria, it will be required to cease carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab.  The deadline for ceasing the Regulated Activity will be upon the expiry of its RegLab FSP, or at such time as the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP in accordance with section 33 of the FSMR.  Please refer to section 8 below for more details.
target_text: Variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission. Variation or cancellation on initiative of the Regulator

question: If a Listed Entity wants to issue Equity Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme but would otherwise go over the allowed 20% limit, what must the notice of meeting include so the holders of Ordinary Securities can approve the issue and the Listed Entity is not prohibited from issuing above the calculated maximum?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number calculated under the 20% Base Amount formula (after subtracting Relevant Issues) unless it first obtains approval from the holders of Ordinary Securities [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. If the Listed Entity is using an Employee Incentive Scheme and is seeking that holder approval as the basis to proceed (within the specified three-year lookback described for scheme issues), the notice of meeting has mandatory content that cannot be left out. Specifically, it must include: (1) a summary of the terms of the scheme; (2) the number of Securities already issued under the scheme since the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List, or since the date of the last approval under the relevant approval route; and (3) the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme after the approval is given [#SRC:a2108df9-4a76-4d9c-8a4a-7e058e5e8113]. Including these items supports the validity of the holder approval that is required to avoid the prohibition on issuing above the calculated maximum.
source_text:
An issue of Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme if within three years before the issue date:
(a)	in the case of a scheme established before the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List – a summary of the terms of the scheme and the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme were set out in in its Approved Prospectus or documents lodged with the Regulator under Rule 2.4.3; or
(b)	the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities have approved the issue of Equity Securities under the scheme as an exception to Rule 9.7.1.  The notice of meeting must have included:
(i)	a summary of the terms of the scheme;
(ii)	the number of Securities issued under the scheme since the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List, or the date of the last approval under this Rule; and
(iii)	the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme following the approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: When an Authorised Person seeks to apply the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach, what governance and documentation must it establish for mapping gross income across current business lines and activities, and how must it maintain those criteria as business activities change, including any prescribed reference framework?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person seeks to apply the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach, it must put in place a defined mapping framework that is both operationally embedded and auditable. Specifically, it must develop specific policies and maintain documented criteria that explain how gross income from its current business lines and activities is mapped into the relevant approach, ensuring the mapping is consistently applied and can be evidenced through documentation [#SRC:e55b981f-c5a0-41dd-ae9a-14f14a7b442d]. In addition, the mapping criteria are not static: the Authorised Person must review and adjust them as appropriate when there are new or changing business activities, so that the mapping remains aligned to the firm’s evolving business profile and continues to reflect current activities [#TGT:a1e9cb4f-8550-418a-b513-ff5763673aa3]. The required mapping documentation must also be prepared in line with the prescribed reference framework identified for this purpose, so that the criteria and policies correspond to the prescribed structure for mapping gross income into the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach [#TGT:a1e9cb4f-8550-418a-b513-ff5763673aa3].
source_text: In accordance with Rule 6.11.3, an Authorised Person seeking to apply the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach must develop specific policies and have documented criteria for mapping gross income for current business lines and activities into the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach. The criteria must be reviewed and adjusted for new or changing business activities as appropriate. The principles for business line mapping are set out below.
target_text: An Authorised Person seeking to apply the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach must develop specific policies and have documented criteria for mapping gross income for current business lines and activities into the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach, as prescribed in App7. The criteria must be reviewed and adjusted for new or changing business activities as appropriate.

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, which reconciliation and custody-check records must be maintained and included in the Resolution Pack, and what minimum frequencies apply to reconciling Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents, counting Safe Custody Assets, and reconciling Client ledger balances to Safe Custody Assets balances?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must ensure that its Resolution Pack includes the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments, because the Resolution Pack is required to contain those reconciliation records as part of the specified record set [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. In parallel, the Authorised Person must perform (and therefore have records evidencing) three minimum-frequency controls: (i) at least every calendar month, reconcile its records of Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents against the monthly statements received from those Third Party Agents; (ii) at least every six months, count all Safe Custody Assets physically held by the Authorised Person or its Nominee Company and reconcile the count to the Authorised Person’s records; and (iii) at least every six months, reconcile individual Client ledger balances with the Authorised Person’s records of Safe Custody Assets balances held in Client Accounts [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6]. Taken together, the Resolution Pack should contain the latest outputs of these reconciliation processes so that the Authorised Person can demonstrate both completion and recency of the required reconciliations and custody checks.
target_text:
An Authorised Person must:
(a)	at least every calendar month, reconcile its records of Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents with monthly statements received from those Third Party Agents;
(b)	at least every six months, count all Safe Custody Assets physically held by the Authorised Person, or its Nominee Company, and reconcile the result of that count to the records of the Authorised Person; and
(c)	at least every six months, reconcile individual Client ledger balances with the Authorised Person's records of Safe Custody Assets balances held in Client Accounts.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity can disclose forecast financial information from a Production Target for its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or for material Mining Project(s), what does it have to include about the key assumptions and the Production Target itself, especially if some assumptions are commercially sensitive?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is permitted to disclose forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, but only in relation to either its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s) [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]. If it chooses to make that disclosure, it must include specific information about how the forecast was determined: it must set out all material economic assumptions used, and it must also include all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Where the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it still has to address them by stating that they are commercially sensitive and explaining the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. The disclosure must also include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, together with the full set of information required to accompany that Production Target [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489].
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to either a Mining Reporting Entity’s:
(1)	Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or
(2)	material Mining Project(s).

question: When an Authorised Person is designing and operating anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems, how must it meet its duty to establish and maintain effective systems and controls to deter, prevent, and report suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes, and to what extent may it incorporate secure authentication, biometrics, and monitoring of customer behaviour metrics as part of those systems and controls?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must establish and maintain effective systems and controls that are capable of deterring and preventing suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes against the Authorised Person and its Customers, and it must also ensure those systems and controls support reporting suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes to the relevant authorities [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596]. In meeting that obligation, the Authorised Person should observe best practices when establishing the required systems and controls, recognising that Financial Crime evolves over time [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]. Those best practices may include incorporating secure authentication, biometrics, and the monitoring of customer behaviour metrics into the anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems and controls, as part of a broader control framework aimed at deterrence, prevention, and effective escalation/reporting of suspected activity [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]. Accordingly, the obligation sets the required outcomes (effective deterrence, prevention, and reporting), while the permission/guidance supports using these specific techniques as optional components to strengthen the overall effectiveness of the systems and controls [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7].
source_text: An Authorised Person should observe best practices when establishing the systems and controls required under Rule 3.3.38, given the evolving nature of Financial Crime. Such practices may include, but are not limited to, incorporating secure authentication, biometrics and the monitoring of customer behaviour metrics into anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems and controls.
target_text:
Fraud and other Financial Crimes: An Authorised Person must establish and maintain effective systems and controls to:
(1)	deter and prevent suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes against the Authorised Person and its Customers; and
(2)	report suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes to the relevant authorities.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation and uses the option that it does not have to follow the usual rule, what must it still put into the disclosure itself?
gold_answer: Even where a Mining Reporting Entity disclosing material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation can use the option that it does not need to comply with the usual disclosure rule (as long as it complies with the listed alternative rules) [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26], it still has to meet the disclosure-content requirements that apply to such disclosures [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]. The Mining Reporting Entity must include a clear, nearby statement that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates, are not disclosed in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, and that it is uncertain whether further evaluation/exploration will ever allow that. It must also include the sources and dates of the estimates; explain any Mineralisation categories used (and whether they match or differ from a Mining Reporting Standard); and cover relevance and reliability. In addition, it must summarise the work and assumptions behind the estimates, provide any newer relevant estimates/data with sources/dates, describe what work is needed to verify them (plus timing and funding), state the classification/reporting standard used, and include a named Competent Person statement confirming the accuracy of specified parts of the disclosure.

question: If someone files a Supplementary Prospectus, does that automatically mean they have to pay an extra fee, or can the Regulator only charge a supplementary fee when it expects substantial extra cost or work—like it can for other filings, applications, authorisations, or on-going supervision?
gold_answer: Filing a Supplementary Prospectus does not automatically result in an extra fee. The specific rule states that the filing itself does not trigger payment unless the review of the Supplementary Prospectus will require the Regulator to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort when conducting its review; only in that situation may the Regulator require payment of a supplementary fee [#SRC:cec237a1-c364-4ed0-9197-dcac6160defb]. The general supplementary-fee provision uses the same threshold—where the Regulator expects substantial additional costs or substantial additional effort—and explains that this permission can apply in a wider set of situations, including dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Putting both together, a Supplementary Prospectus filing is treated as a type of filing that normally carries no extra charge, but it can become chargeable if the Regulator anticipates that reviewing it will materially increase the resources needed, consistent with the broader approach to supplementary fees.
source_text: The filing of a Supplementary Prospectus does not trigger the payment of a fee unless the review of the Supplementary Prospectus will require the Regulator to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort when conducting its review, in which event the Regulator may require payment of a supplementary fee in accordance with Rule 1.2.4.
target_text:
Supplementary fees
The Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee in circumstances where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing or when conducting on-going supervision.

question: When conducting an investigation, may the Investigator both enter a person’s business premises to inspect and copy documents and also compel that access through a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or any other person, and what limits apply to the timing and relevance of the documents?
gold_answer: Across the two provisions, the Investigator is permitted to enter business premises to inspect and copy documents, but the exercise of that access is framed in two complementary ways: a general investigative permission tied to document relevance, and a notice-based mechanism that can compel a person to allow entry. Under the source, the Investigator may enter business premises for the purpose of inspecting and copying any documents where those documents are relevant for the purposes of the investigation [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767]. Under the target, the Investigator may, by written notice, require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to permit the Investigator to enter that person’s business premises during normal business hours for the purpose of inspecting and copying documents on the premises [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Read together, the entry/inspection/copying purpose is consistent in both texts, while the target adds procedural and temporal constraints (written notice; normal business hours) and broadens who can be required to grant access, and the source emphasizes that the documents inspected/copied must be relevant to the investigation.
source_text: Power to enter premises and inspect and copy documents . Section 206(1)(e) of FSMR permits the Investigator to enter business premises for the purpose of inspecting and copying any documents where relevant for the purposes of the investigation.

question: Before a Customer becomes bound by the Governing Contract, what information must a Third Party Provider provide, and how does that obligation align with the requirement that the Governing Contract itself include specified content unless the parties agree otherwise in writing?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider must ensure that, before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract, the Customer is provided with the information that is required to be given at that pre‑contract stage [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]. In parallel, unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer otherwise agree in writing, the Governing Contract between the Third Party Provider and their Customers must itself contain specified information covering: details about the Third Party Provider (including identity, ADGM office contact details, and regulator/FSP details); the Third Party Services (including key characteristics, required Customer identifiers, consent process, receipt timing, service timeframes, and usage limits); charges and exchange rates; agreed communications and information delivery arrangements; safeguards and corrective measures (including notification periods for unauthorised/incorrectly executed Third Party Transactions, fraud/security contact procedures, stopping conditions, and liability/refund-related terms); changes and termination terms; and redress mechanisms (including applicable law/courts and any alternative dispute resolution) [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Taken together, the Third Party Provider must both provide the required information before the Customer is bound and, absent a written variation, embed the required disclosures and operational terms within the Governing Contract itself.
source_text:
A Third Party Provider must provide a Customer the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract.
Information provision during period of the Governing Contract

question: Where, following an enquiry into a complaint or allegation, the Listing Authority concludes the information is accurate, constitutes Inside Information, and is not covered by an exemption from Disclosure, what procedural steps must the Listing Authority take in asking the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure, and how does that interact with the issuance and subsequent publication of an ‘aware letter’ and the Reporting Entity’s response?
gold_answer: Following an enquiry arising from complaints or allegations of non-compliance, the Listing Authority first reaches a threshold view on the information: it must be satisfied that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within an exemption from Disclosure. If those conditions are met, the Listing Authority will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter (i.e., the request to disclose is the procedural next step once the Listing Authority has formed that view) [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944]. If the Listing Authority considers the information should have been Disclosed earlier, it may also issue an ‘aware letter’ or take other relevant action, which frames the Listing Authority’s concern about timeliness [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944]. After an ‘aware letter’ is issued, the process continues with the Reporting Entity providing a response; once that response has been received and reviewed by the Listing Authority, the Listing Authority will usually Disclose both the ‘aware letter’ and the Reporting Entity’s response together, to ensure the market in the Listed Entity’s Securities is aware of the enquiries and the Reporting Entity’s response [#TGT:f4e70987-8287-425e-a207-54a123dfa6f4].
source_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Complaints or allegations of non-compliance by Reporting Entities
If, as a result of the enquiry, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within exemption from Disclosure provided by Rule 7.2.2, the Listing Authority will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1.  If the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an ‘aware letter’ (see paragraphs 187 to 189 above), or take other relevant action.
target_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Aware Letters
When a Reporting Entity’s response has been received and reviewed by the Listing Authority, both the ‘aware letter’ and the Reporting Entity’s response will usually be Disclosed together by the Listing Authority, so that the market in the Listed Entity’s Securities is aware that the Listing Authority has made enquiries of the Reporting Entity about the timeliness of its Disclosures, and of the Reporting Entity’s response to those enquiries.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information and also discloses the key underlying assumptions and outcomes of a relevant Technical Study used to support an Ore Reserves estimate, what must it include regarding the economic assumptions, and how should it address any claim that those assumptions are commercially sensitive?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must ensure its disclosure is complete across both the forecast financial information assumptions and the Technical Study disclosures supporting an Ore Reserves estimate. For the forecast financial information, it must include all material economic assumptions employed, and it must also include all other material assumptions utilised. If it considers the material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must provide a statement that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions, rather than omitting them without context [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. In parallel, where the entity has carried out a relevant Technical Study (a preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study) to achieve the required level of confidence in the modifying factors used to determine an estimate of Ore Reserves, it must disclose the key underlying assumptions and outcomes of that Technical Study [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464]. Taken together, the disclosures should allow users to understand both the economic basis of the forecast financial information and the principal assumptions/outcomes underpinning the Ore Reserves estimate.
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Pursuant to Rule 11.6.1(1)(a), in order to achieve the required level of confidence in the modifying factors to determine an estimate of Ore Reserves, a Mining Reporting Entity will need to have carried out a relevant Technical Study (preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study ).  The key underlying assumptions and outcomes of the Technical Study are also to be disclosed.

question: When an Authorised Person has eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and is measuring the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, can it recognise the Collateral’s effect, and if it does, how must it pick and apply FCSA or FCCA across the Non Trading Book and the Trading Book?
gold_answer: Yes. If an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under the specified measurement basis, it may recognise the effect of that Collateral when measuring E, subject to following the recognition framework referenced in the permission [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. Once it recognises collateral effects, it must follow strict approach rules based on book classification. In the Non Trading Book, the Authorised Person must choose one approach—either the FCSA or the FCCA—to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, must apply that chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book, and must not use a combination of both approaches within that book [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]. For SFTs in the Trading Book, the rule is tighter: for any pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412].
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for any SFT in the Non Trading Book. The Authorised Person must apply the chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book and must not use a combination of both approaches. For a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from any SFT in the Trading Book, an Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.

question: When the Regulator discloses Confidential Information, may it make the permission to disclose subject to conditions, including requirements around obtaining consents and ensuring the recipient applies disclosure restrictions that are at least equivalent to the relevant confidentiality restrictions?
gold_answer: Yes. The framework permits the Regulator, when making a disclosure of Confidential Information, to attach conditions to the permission to disclose, to the extent the Regulator considers appropriate. Those conditions may address how the disclosure is managed, including requiring the obtaining of consents and, where appropriate, requiring that information received is subjected to restrictions on further disclosure that are at least equivalent to the relevant confidentiality restrictions. This means the Regulator can structure the permission so that disclosure is not unconditional, but instead is controlled through specified safeguards that govern the handling of the Confidential Information by the recipient. The same permission also allows the Regulator to restrict the uses to which the disclosed Confidential Information may be put, reinforcing that both onward disclosure and downstream use can be constrained as part of the disclosure arrangement. These powers are described as enabling the Regulator to impose conditions on the information disclosed and to restrict uses [#SRC:5b971fba-9c2c-40a0-9b54-e38c1d4d3350], and are reflected in the permission to disclose being made subject to conditions (including consents and equivalent restrictions) insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate [#TGT:98d99b60-b14d-4468-becd-e2c79c8f8b4a].
source_text:
Section 199(3) of the FSMR enables the Regulator to, among other things:
(a)	impose conditions on the information disclosed, which may relate to, among other things, the obtaining of consents or, where appropriate, subjecting information received to restrictions on disclosure that are at least equivalent to those set out in section 198, per paragraph 199(3)(a); and
(b)	restrict the uses to which the Confidential Information disclosed may be put.
target_text:
Any disclosure by the Regulator pursuant to subsection  ‎(1) may include, insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate, provisions—
(a)	making any permission to disclose Confidential Information subject to conditions (which may relate to the obtaining of consents, subjecting information received to restrictions on disclosure of Confidential Information at least equivalent to those set out in section 198 or any other matter); and
(b)	restricting the uses to which Confidential Information disclosed may be put.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity is permitted to disclose forecast financial information derived from a Production Target in connection with its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or material Mining Project(s), what specific content must that disclosure include regarding the assumptions used and the underlying Production Target?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may disclose forecast financial information derived from a Production Target in relation to either its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s) [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]. When it makes that type of disclosure, the disclosure must include detailed information about the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, including all material economic assumptions employed, plus all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must include a statement that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. In addition, the disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all information required to be provided for that Production Target [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489].
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to either a Mining Reporting Entity’s:
(1)	Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or
(2)	material Mining Project(s).

question: How does an Authorised Person work out the weighted average Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate across countries, and how is that rate then used to calculate the Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by multiplying its Total Risk Exposure Amount by a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to the jurisdictions where its private sector credit exposures are located [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]. To compute that weighted average rate, it must break the calculation into steps across all relevant jurisdictions. For each jurisdiction where it has private sector credit exposures, it takes the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to those private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction and divides it by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions. It then multiplies that share by the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate that applies in that jurisdiction. After doing this for every jurisdiction, it adds up (sums) all of those jurisdiction-level contributions to arrive at one weighted average rate [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124]. That final weighted average rate is the rate used as the multiplier in the CET1 buffer amount calculation.
source_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.
target_text:
Weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates. The weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates shall be calculated by:
(a)	for each jurisdiction in which the Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures, dividing the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions and multiplying it by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate in that jurisdiction; and
(b)	summing those contributions across all jurisdictions.

question: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider can agree in writing that the rule about liability for charges does not apply. If they do not make that written agreement, what must the Payment Service Provider pay the Payment Service User when the Payment Service Provider does not execute a Payment Transaction, executes it wrongly, or executes it late?
gold_answer: Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider are allowed to agree in writing that certain rules will not apply, including the rule dealing with liability for charges [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. If they do not make that written agreement (or if the situation is not covered by what they agreed), the Payment Service Provider must follow the stated liability outcome for execution problems: the Payment Service Provider is liable to its Payment Service User for any charges that the Payment Service User is responsible for, and for any interest the Payment Service User must pay, when those amounts arise because the Payment Service Provider did not execute the Payment Transaction, executed it defectively, or executed it late [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa]. This means the Payment Service Provider’s obligation is tied to the consequences of its non-execution, defective execution, or late execution, and it covers both (i) charges borne by the Payment Service User and (ii) interest the Payment Service User must pay due to that failure. The written agreement option is simply a permitted way to switch off the identified rule(s) for non-Natural Person users.
target_text: A Payment Service Provider is liable to its Payment Service User for any charges for which the Payment Service User is responsible and any interest which the Payment Service User must pay as a consequence of the non-execution, defective or late execution of a Payment Transaction by the Payment Service Provider.

question: For a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity, what is the latest time by which it must disclose the quarterly report, and what minimum subject-matter must that quarterly report cover for the entity and all controlled entities on a consolidated basis (if applicable)?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose its quarterly report no later than one month after the end of the relevant quarter [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1]. The report that must be disclosed is a report for each quarter of its financial year and must cover, in respect of the Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities (on a consolidated basis, if applicable), specified information about Petroleum-related activities and positions [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62].
