At a minimum, the quarterly report must include: details of activities relating to Petroleum (Exploration, and production and development, or statements that there were no such activities); a summary of expenditure incurred relating to Petroleum (Exploration activities, and production and development); the Petroleum Tenements held at quarter end (including location, percentage interest held, and beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements); and Petroleum Tenements acquired or disposed of during the quarter (including location and beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements) [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62]. In addition, at least once every 12 months the report must address the Summary of Reserves and Resources requirement (unless included in the annual report) and state when the previous and upcoming disclosures of that summary were and are to be made [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62].
source_text: Quarterly Reports – Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entities. A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose the report required by Rule 12.13.1 no later than one month after the end of the quarter.

question: When calculating Exposure value for on-balance sheet derivatives (including written credit protection), how must a firm determine the components that are summed (IFRS on-balance sheet amount plus a potential future exposure add-on), and how must that approach be aligned with the requirement to calculate replacement cost and potential future exposure differently for margined versus unmargined netting sets, including the cap applicable to a margined netting set’s EAD?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet derivatives, including written credit protection, the firm must calculate the Exposure value as a sum of two elements: (i) the on-balance sheet value determined in accordance with IFRS and (ii) an add-on for potential future exposure calculated under the specified App 4 rules [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]. In applying the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk for derivatives and long settlement transactions, the firm must ensure that the replacement cost (RC) and potential future exposure (PFE) components used in its counterparty credit risk framework are calculated differently depending on whether the relevant netting set is margined or unmargined [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941]. Where the exposure is measured on a margined netting set basis, the firm must also apply the constraint that the EAD for that margined netting set is capped at the EAD of the same netting set calculated on an unmargined basis [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941]. Together, these requirements mean the summed Exposure value for derivatives must incorporate an IFRS-based amount plus a PFE add-on, while the PFE (and RC) mechanics and any EAD cap must reflect whether netting is treated as margined or unmargined.
source_text:
In relation to on-balance sheet items:
a.	for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14;
b.	for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and
c.	for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
target_text: Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). The replacement cost (RC) and the potential future exposure (PFE) components must be calculated differently for margined and unmargined netting sets. The EAD for a margined netting set is to be capped at the EAD of the same netting set calculated on an unmargined basis.

question: When the Regulator is satisfied that doing so is in the interest of the ADGM/Abu Dhabi Global Market, may it direct a Reporting Entity to disclose specified information (including to the market) or take other steps, and on what basis can it set the terms and conditions for that direction?
gold_answer: Across both passages, the Regulator is permitted to issue a direction to a Reporting Entity when it has reached the satisfaction threshold that the action is in the interest of the ADGM/Abu Dhabi Global Market. In that circumstance, the direction may require the Reporting Entity to disclose specified information, and the Regulator may alternatively (or additionally) require the Reporting Entity to take other steps the Regulator considers appropriate, reflecting a broad discretionary power tied to the Regulator’s assessment of what serves the market’s interests [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] and [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94]. The TARGET further clarifies that the disclosure may be to the market and that the Regulator may impose such a direction “on such terms and conditions as determined by the Regulator,” indicating that the Regulator controls the parameters and any conditions attached to compliance with the direction [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94]. Read together, the permission is triggered by the Regulator’s satisfaction as to the relevant market interest and then extends to both the content of the required disclosure and the ancillary steps and conditions the Regulator deems appropriate.
source_text: Section 84 of the FSMR gives the Regulator the power to direct a Reporting Entity to Disclose specified information or take such other steps as the Regulator considers appropriate where it is satisfied that it is in the interest of the ADGM to do so.
target_text:
Miscellaneous . Regulator's powers of Direction
The Regulator may, if it is satisfied that it is in the interests of the Abu Dhabi Global Market to do so—
(a)	direct a Reporting Entity to disclose specified information to the market or take such other steps as the Regulator considers appropriate; or
(b)	impose on a Reporting Entity any additional continuing obligations;
on such terms and conditions as determined by the Regulator.

question: What must a Relevant Person do to assess and manage risks linked to NFTF business and the use of eKYC Systems as part of its overall money laundering risk assessment?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must take appropriate steps to identify and assess the money laundering risks to which its business is exposed, taking into consideration the nature, size and complexity of its activities, and it must take into account that these risks include terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance (including non-compliance with Targeted Financial Sanctions) [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. As part of that business-wide assessment, it should include an assessment of the risks associated with carrying on NFTF business, particularly where it uses eKYC Systems [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2]. When identifying and assessing risks, the Relevant Person must also consider (to the extent relevant) vulnerabilities tied to customers, countries/geographic areas, products and services, distribution channels and business partners, transaction complexity and volume, new products and business practices, and the use of new or developing technologies—areas that can be directly affected by eKYC and NFTF activity [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. It must then take appropriate measures to ensure any identified risk is reflected in day-to-day operations and mitigated, including for new products, new customers, and changes to its business profile [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. The assessment should also consider incorporating relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator and other relevant bodies [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2].
source_text: A business risk assessment under Rule ‎6.1.1(b) should include an assessment of the risks associated with the carrying on of NFTF business, particularly the use of eKYC Systems. The assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and any other relevant bodies.

question: What must a Payment Service Provider tell a Payment Service User before the user is bound, and what must also be written into a Framework Contract—especially for charges, exchange rates, and the information needed to start or execute a Payment Order?
gold_answer: Before a Payment Service User is bound by a Single Payment Service Contract, a Payment Service Provider must provide or make available important details about the Payment Service. This includes what information or unique identifier the Payment Service User must give so a Payment Order can be properly initiated or executed, the maximum time for the Payment Service to be executed, the charges payable (and a breakdown where applicable), and (where applicable) the actual or Reference Exchange Rate for the Payment Transaction [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55]. In addition, a Framework Contract between a Payment Service Provider and a Payment Service User must include a broader set of information, unless the parties otherwise agree in writing where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person. The Framework Contract must cover, among other things, the same core items (identifiers needed for Payment Orders, maximum execution time, and charges and exchange-rate details), and it must also include extra specifics such as charges connected to information being provided or made available, how exchange rates are determined, and how and how often information under the chapter will be provided or made available [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b].

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a disclosure containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, what must it do to ensure the disclosure is both properly attributed to named Competent Person(s) and not released without the Competent Person(s)’ prior written consent as to the form and context of the presentation?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity must satisfy two linked requirements when it discloses Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves. First, the disclosure must include specific attribution statements: it must state that the disclosure is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s); it must also state whether each Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party (and if not, identify the Competent Person’s employer); and it must state the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79]. Second, the statement referred to in the relevant framework must only be disclosed with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the estimated resources/reserves and supporting information are presented in the disclosure [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e]. Together, these obligations mean the Petroleum Reporting Entity must both obtain the required written consent for the presentation and include the required identification and status details for the named Competent Person(s) in the disclosure.
source_text:
Competent Persons . The statement referred to in Rule 12.15.2:
(1)	must only be disclosed with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the estimated Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Prospective Resources, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure; and
(2)	only applies the first time a Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses original or updated estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves where:
(a)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves references the earlier disclosure containing the statements and consent referred to in Rules 12.15.2 and 12.15.3(1); and
(b)	the Petroleum Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure, and that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . A disclosure by a Petroleum Reporting Entity containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: When calculating Exposure value for Derivatives (including written credit protection) that fall within the SA-CCR framework, what steps must be followed to ensure the Exposure value is computed as a sum of the IFRS on-balance sheet amount and a potential future exposure add-on, and how must this be aligned with the requirement to calculate EAD separately for each netting set using the SA-CCR components?
gold_answer: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), the firm must calculate the Exposure value as a sum of two elements: (i) the on-balance sheet value determined in accordance with IFRS, and (ii) an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated under the specified App 4 rules for derivatives add-ons [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]. Where the derivative is within the SA-CCR scope, the procedure for quantifying the counterparty credit risk measure requires calculating EAD separately for each netting set and determining it using the SA-CCR formula EAD = alpha * (RC + PFE), with alpha fixed at 1.4, RC computed under the referenced replacement cost rules, and PFE computed under the referenced potential future exposure rule [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918]. Operationally, this means the IFRS on-balance sheet value provides the accounting-based component of Exposure value, while the add-on/PFE component must be produced using the SA-CCR methodology on a netting-set basis, ensuring the “sum” requirement for Exposure value is met consistently with the SA-CCR decomposition into RC and PFE.
source_text:
In relation to on-balance sheet items:
a.	for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14;
b.	for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and
c.	for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
target_text:
Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). EAD is to be calculated separately for each netting set. It is determined as follows:
EAD = alpha* (RC + PFE)
where:
alpha = 1.4
RC = the replacement cost calculated according to Rules A4.6.19 to A4.6.24
PFE = the amount for potential future exposure calculated according to Rule A4.6.26

question: When does a message count as an Offer of Securities because it is a communication to any person (in any form) that helps an investor decide to buy or subscribe, and when is it not treated as an offer because it is linked to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, ongoing reporting to the Regulator or a Recognised Investment Exchange, or another exempt communication in Rules?
gold_answer: Both passages describe an Offer of Securities as a very broad category of message: it covers any communication to any person, in any form or by any means, that presents information about the Offer and the Securities offered (including the terms of the Offer) in a way that enables an investor to decide to buy or subscribe to those Securities [#SRC:b3c9bf5b-e0ac-4be7-badf-15646cde6e09] [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310]. So you look at what the message does: does it give enough information about the Offer and the Securities for an investor to make a buy/subscribe decision, regardless of whether it is an email, website, presentation, or other medium? The TARGET then adds important carve-outs: even if a communication looks like it could influence an investor, it is excluded if it is in connection with trading of Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, if it is made to comply with the on going reporting requirements of the Regulator or a Recognised Investment Exchange, or if it is another type of communication that Rules prescribe as exempt [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310].
source_text:
MARKETS RULES – OFFERS OF SECURITIES TO THE PUBLIC
Offers of Securities
As set out in section 59 of FSMR, an Offer of Securities to the Public is “a communication to any person in any form or by any means presenting information on the Offer and the Securities offered so as to enable an investor to decide to buy or subscribe to those Securities”.
target_text:
General prohibitions and definitions. Definition of an Offer of Securities
An Offer of Securities means a communication to any person in any form or by any means, presenting information on the terms of the Offer and the Securities offered, so as to enable an investor to decide to buy or subscribe to those Securities but excluding—
(a)	any communication in connection with the trading of Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange;
(b)	any communication made for the purposes of complying with the on going reporting requirements of the Regulator or a Recognised Investment Exchange; or
(c)	any other communication prescribed in Rules as an exempt communication.

question: In identifying vulnerabilities linked to new or developing technologies, what must a Relevant Person do to ensure its assessment covers eKYC Systems used in NFTF business and reflects any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator or other competent bodies, while also ensuring the resulting risks are mitigated in day-to-day operations?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must identify and assess the money laundering risks to which its business is exposed and, when doing so, must take into account (to the extent relevant) vulnerabilities relating to the use of new or developing technologies for both new and pre-existing products and services [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. Consistent with that requirement, its business risk assessment should include an assessment of the risks associated with carrying on NFTF business, particularly the use of eKYC Systems, because those technology-enabled processes can form part of its products, services, activity profiles, and delivery mechanisms [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2] [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. The Relevant Person must also take into account that money laundering risks include terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance, so the NFTF/eKYC analysis should be framed within that broader risk set [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. In addition, the assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2]. Finally, it must take appropriate measures to ensure any identified risk is taken into account in day-to-day operations and is mitigated, including in relation to new products, new customers, and changes to its business profile [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851].
source_text: A business risk assessment under Rule ‎6.1.1(b) should include an assessment of the risks associated with the carrying on of NFTF business, particularly the use of eKYC Systems. The assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and any other relevant bodies.

question: If an Authorised Person has an SFT with no qualifying cross product Netting agreement, what must it use to calculate E, and when can it take into account eligible financial Collateral it has taken for that SFT?
gold_answer: Where an SFT is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, an Authorised Person must calculate E for the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure based on what it provided under the SFT: if it lent Securities or sold Securities with a commitment to repurchase them later at a specified price and date, E is the latest fair value of the Securities lent or sold; if it lent cash by borrowing Securities or paid cash to buy Securities with a commitment to resell them later at a specified price and date, E is the amount of cash lent or paid [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e]. Separately, if the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT, it is permitted to recognise the effect of that Collateral in its exposure measurement, but only where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure for that SFT is determined using the applicable measurement approach referenced for this purpose and the collateral effect is recognised under the specified collateral-recognition framework [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778].
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text:
Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must determine E, for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT which is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement as follows:
(a)	in the case where the Authorised Person has lent Securities to a Counterparty or sold Securities to a Counterparty with a commitment to repurchase those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the latest fair value of the Securities lent or sold; and
(b)	in the case where the Authorised Person has lent cash to a Counterparty through the borrowing of Securities from the Counterparty or paid cash for the purchase of Securities from a Counterparty with a commitment to resell those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the amount of cash lent or paid.

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange admits a Financial Instrument to trading and it uses a benchmark or index from a Price Reporting Agency, what checks must the exchange do to make sure the Price Reporting Agency meets the required standards?
gold_answer: If a Recognised Investment Exchange is admitting to trading a Financial Instrument that references an underlying benchmark or index provided by a Price Reporting Agency, the exchange must carry out appropriate due diligence to ensure the Price Reporting Agency meets the relevant requirements [#SRC:69082061-a103-4087-acae-fa41e87fd0da]. In practical terms, the checks must cover whether the Price Reporting Agency has fair, non-discriminatory procedures for establishing prices and whether those procedures are made public; and whether it can demonstrate adequate transparency over its methodology, calculation, and inputs so users can understand how the benchmark or index is derived and what its potential limitations are [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. The exchange should also assess whether, where appropriate, the Price Reporting Agency gives priority to concluded transactions and has measures to minimise selective reporting; whether it is of good standing and repute as an independent and objective price reporting agency or index provider; and whether it has a sound corporate governance framework [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a]. The due diligence must further consider whether the Price Reporting Agency has adequate arrangements to avoid staff conflicts of interest that could materially adversely affect the price establishment process, and whether it maintains adequate complaint resolution mechanisms for its assessment process and methodology [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a].
source_text: When admitting to trading a Financial Instrument that references an underlying benchmark or index provided by a Price Reporting Agency, a Recognised Investment Exchange must undertake appropriate due diligence to ensure that the Price Reporting Agency meets the requirements in Rule 3.11.2.

question: If an Authorised Person holds CET1 Capital instruments in a Relevant Entity, when does that holding count as a significant investment, and what must the Authorised Person do with that holding when working out its CET1 Capital?
gold_answer: A holding by an Authorised Person in a Relevant Entity must be treated as a significant investment if it meets any of the listed triggers: the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by the Relevant Entity; or the Authorised Person both has Close Links with the Relevant Entity and owns its CET1 Capital instruments; or the Authorised Person owns the Relevant Entity’s CET1 Capital instruments and, while the Relevant Entity is not included in consolidation under the Rules, it is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for IFRS financial reporting [#SRC:c9f19d0b-d036-4cfe-88ba-7e2528a70c11]. When the holding meets that definition, the CET1 deduction requirements apply: subject to the other Rules in the Section, the Authorised Person must deduct from the calculation of its CET1 Capital the applicable amount of its direct and indirect holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person has a significant investment in those entities [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]. This links the definition of “significant investment” to the required CET1 deduction treatment for those holdings.
source_text:
CET1 Deductions - significant investment in a Relevant Entity. For the purposes of Rules 3.10.7(g) and (h), an investment by an Authorised Person in a Relevant Entity must be considered as a significant investment if it meets any of the following conditions:
(a)	the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity;
(b)	the Authorised Person has Close Links with that entity and owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity; or
(c)	the Authorised Person owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity and the entity is not included in consolidation pursuant to Chapter 8 of these Rules but is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for the purposes of financial reporting under the International Financial Reporting Standards.

question: If a Recognised Body cannot follow a direction (like giving access for inspection or suspending an activity), what can the Regulator do, and when does it usually consider revoking the Recognition Order?
gold_answer: The Regulator can give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, and those steps may include giving the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect the premises or documents there, as well as suspending the carrying on of any activity for a period set out in the direction [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500]. But the Regulator will usually consider revoking the Recognition Order where it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction, meaning the direction route is not workable in practice [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]. The Regulator will also usually consider revocation if the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences, or if for some other reason it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give a direction under its power to give directions. Separately, revocation is usually considered if the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the 12 months after the Recognition Order took effect, or has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending with the day the Recognition Order is revoked [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a].
target_text: The Regulator has the power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps in order to secure its compliance with the Recognition Requirements. Those steps may include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body's premises for the purposes of inspecting those premises or any documents on the premises and the suspension of the carrying on of any activity by the Recognised Body for the period specified in the direction.

question: When a person proposes to acquire or increase the level of control in a Domestic Firm and is also required to obtain the prior written approval of the Regulator, what written notice must be given, to whom, and in what form must it be submitted?
gold_answer: Where a person proposes either to acquire or increase the level of control in a Domestic Firm, the person must submit a written notice to us, and that notice must be in the form we shall set [#SRC:4068f5d7-33d4-473c-b314-4ee227d051bd]. In parallel, where a Person is required to obtain the prior written approval of the Regulator, that Person must provide written notice to the Regulator, and the notice must be in such form as the Regulator shall prescribe [#TGT:9b45a767-f8c2-493b-b0ae-d9f349767787]. Taken together, the obligation is not merely to notify, but to do so in the specific format mandated by the relevant authority (us for the Domestic Firm control change context, and the Regulator for the prior-approval context). The Source further indicates that the notice functions as an application that may be assessed for approval, objection, or conditions, and that incomplete or unclear submissions may trigger a written request for further information, affecting when the decision period starts [#SRC:4068f5d7-33d4-473c-b314-4ee227d051bd].
source_text: Controllers - Our approval. Under GEN 8.8.5(1), a person who proposes either to acquire or increase the level of control in a Domestic Firm must provide written notice to us in such form as we shall set. We may approve of, object to or impose conditions relating to the proposed acquisition or the proposed increase in the level of control of the firm. If the information in the written application lodged with us is incomplete or unclear, we may in writing request further clarification or information. We may do so at any time during the processing of such an application. The period of 90 days within which we will make a decision will not commence until such clarification or additional information is provided to our satisfaction. We may, in our absolute discretion, agree to a shorter period for processing an application where an applicant requests for such a period, provided all the information required is available to us.
target_text: A Person who is required to obtain the prior written approval of the Regulator pursuant to Rule ‎8.8.4(1) must provide written notice to the Regulator in such form as the Regulator shall prescribe.

question: When an Authorised Person is onboarding a Retail Client for a trading account to buy and sell OTC Leveraged Products, what does the Authorised Person have to do about giving a separate risk disclosure statement, and what must that statement say about big losses, leverage, and stop-loss orders?
gold_answer: As part of onboarding and before opening a trading account that lets a Retail Client buy and sell OTC Leveraged Products, the Authorised Person must give the Retail Client a separate risk disclosure statement in good time before doing any business for that Retail Client [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8]. That statement must prominently warn that the Retail Client can lose substantially more than the initial margin they posted, and it must also set out additional required risk points, including that the statement may not cover every risk; the Retail Client could lose all capital outlay and any profits not redeemed; losses can build up quickly; and leverage amplifies losses when they happen [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955]. It must also explain that margin-trading limits, stop-loss limits, or other controls may not work or may fail, and where stop-loss orders are relevant, it must clearly say whether the stop-loss is “guaranteed”; if it is not guaranteed, it must explain that it may not limit losses in highly volatile market conditions [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955]. The statement must further cover slippage risk and note that most Retail Clients lose money in these products [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955].

question: When a Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is transmitted using a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, what information must the Payment Service Provider still provide immediately after initiation to the Payer (and, where applicable, the Payee), and what general information may it omit because another Payment Service Provider has provided or will provide it under the Framework Contract?
gold_answer: For an individual Payment Transaction where the Payment Order is transmitted by way of a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider for that single Payment Transaction remains required to provide or make available, immediately after initiation of the Payment Order, the post‑initiation information to the Payer and, where applicable, the Payee. This includes confirmation that initiation with the Payer’s Payment Service Provider was successful, a reference to identify the Payment Transaction (including the Payer and Payee and any information transferred with the Payment Order), the transaction amount in the currency used, any charges (and where applicable a breakdown), any exchange rate used (or a reference) and the post‑conversion amount, the date the Payment Service Provider received the Payment Order, and the Credit Value Date, as set out in the obligation [#TGT:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622]. Separately, where the general information has been provided or will be provided under the Framework Contract by another Payment Service Provider, the Payment Service Provider for the single transaction is permitted not to provide or make available that general information for the individual transaction, subject to the stated condition [#SRC:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2].
source_text: Where a Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is transmitted by way of a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider in respect of that single Payment Transaction need not provide or make available under Rule 19.5.1 the general information which has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in respect of a Framework Contract.

question: What does a Listed Entity have to do within two Business Days after issuing Restricted Securities to ensure a holding lock is put in place, and what must it (and any Security Holder or Controller under a Restriction Agreement) not do during the Restriction Period about releasing that lock?
gold_answer: Within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, the Listed Entity must obtain an undertaking from a suitable entity (such as a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator considers suitable) and submit that undertaking to the Regulator [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. The undertaking must cover two key points: the entity will place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities it holds, and it will not release that holding lock unless it first has the Regulator’s prior written consent. At the same time, during the Restriction Period, the Listed Entity, Security Holder, or Controller that is subject to a Restriction Agreement is prohibited from trying to change the restriction framework by amending an executed Restriction Agreement, and is also prohibited from asking for or agreeing to the release of a holding lock that has been imposed under the relevant mechanism [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d]. Together, these requirements mean the lock must be promptly documented and filed, and no party covered by the Restriction Agreement should initiate or consent to a release during the Restriction Period.
source_text:
Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. During a Restriction Period, a Listed Entity, Security Holder or Controller subject to a Restriction Agreement must not:
(1)	amend an executed Restriction Agreement; or
(2)	ask for or agree to the release of a holding lock that has been imposed in accordance with Rule 9.6.9.
target_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: For an Authorised Person, what conditions must be satisfied to be treated as Category 2, and how does that classification differ from Category 1 where the Financial Services Permission covers deposit-taking or managing a PSIAu?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is in Category 2 where its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (and not merely acting as Matched Principal), its dealing activities are not limited in scope in the way contemplated for certain limited dealing permissions, and it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5 [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f]. The Target text reinforces that Category 2 status is determinatively driven by authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, together with the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, and it also clarifies that where dealing is limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the firm’s activities fall within Category 3A rather than Category 2 [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. By contrast, Category 1 is determinatively based on authorisation to Accept Deposits or to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account that is a PSIAu, provided the Authorised Person does not meet Category 5; other authorisations may exist but do not drive the Category 1 classification [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66].
source_text:
An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal);
(b)	its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and
(c)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5.
Category 3A
Guidance
A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).
